dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, are we ever gonna get these thermostats turned down in Almaty, or what? I mean, seriously, are they just, like, trying to freeze us out then charge us more?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Uh, well, actually, the akimat, they've announced the start date for the end of the heating season. It's, um, April 10th.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Almaty akimat (local government administration) has announced the start date for the end of the heating season. ... Heating will be turned off in stages beginning April 10.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: April 10th? Today's the seventh! And it's supposed to be, like, what, 21 degrees today? Why are we waiting three more days?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: April tenth? Today's the seventh! And it's supposed to be, like, what, twenty one degrees today? Why are we waiting three more days?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On April 7... Temperatures will range from 8"10ÂC at night to 21"23ÂC during the day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, yeah. So, their rule, you know, is that it has to be above eight degrees Celsius for five consecutive days. That's, um, the national hydrometeorological service rule.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, yeah. So, their rule, you know, is that it has to be above eight degrees Celsius for five consecutive days. That's, um, the national hydrometeorological service rule.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Officials previously stated that heating in Almaty is turned off once the average daily outdoor temperature remains above 8ÂC for five consecutive calendar days, as recorded by the national hydrometeorological service.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Five days? So, they're saying it hasn't been consistently warm enough until now? Even with, like, twenty-degree days forecast? That just sounds like, I don't know, an excuse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Five days? So, they're saying it hasn't been consistently warm enough until now? Even with, like, twenty-degree days forecast? That just sounds like, I don't know, an excuse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article does mention, um, partly cloudy skies, rain, thunderstorms... you know, fluctuating temperatures. Like 8-10 at night.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: See? So why is Almaty so special? Why do we have to wait? Is it, like, connected to those high tariffs the Akim was asked about? Just trying to squeeze a few more days of charges out of everyone?
